intro: Doronicum echinatum, commonly known as the rough mountain daffodil, is a perennial flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe. It belongs to the family Primulaceae and is characterized by its distinctive, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from yellow to orange. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and features lance-shaped leaves with a rough texture. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun to partial shade. Doronicum echinatum is often found in alpine and subalpine environments, where it contributes to the biodiversity of rocky and grassy habitats.
